author: John Funk, The Plain Dealer
title: Sustainability Summit tackles clean water (photos)
text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- More than 560 Greater Clevelanders packed Cleveland Public Auditorium for two days this week to develop strategies to make the region more sustainable.
About half of the crowd at the city's seventh annual sustainability summit attended previous summits, and more than 100 of them have been actively engaged in sustainability working groups created during those summits, said Jenita McGowan, the city's sustainability chief.
About 17 percent of this year's crowd said they were from the business community, 12 percent identified themselves as government employees and 11 percent as higher education employees, said McGowan.
Organized by Weatherhead School of Management at Case Western Reserve University professors David Cooperrider and Ron Fry, the annual summit crowds have repeatedly shown grassroots democracy in action.
Each year, the participants have organized themselves around topics of interest. The resulting groups then have spent years working to put programs in place.
Each summit has been focused on a different topic, including energy efficiency, renewable energy, recycling, emphasizing local foods, and this year's topic, clean water.
The focus of clean water will work to develop programs and practices to keep storm water from overwhelming sewage treatment plants and to make consumers aware of products containing nano-sized plastic pellets that are polluting the oceans, as well as the Great Lakes.
In remarks opening the two-day summit, Mayor Frank Jackson reminded the crowd who the city has been doing this for.
"People are the reason we are doing this work," he said. "We are doing this for the people who live, work and visit our community."
We are positioning and moving Cleveland in to the future in order to create a sustainable economy that creates opportunities for economic prosperity, increases quality of life and improves the physical and social health of our community in order to make Cleveland a city of choice," he said.
